## Meeting Overview

This document presents the latest event study results comparing baseline (no jackknife) and jackknife approaches across three specifications:

- **Specification A**: Baseline spending only
- **Specification B**: Baseline spending + Income quartiles
- **Specification C**: Baseline spending + Income quartiles * Reform types

Each specification is shown with both the full-sample estimates (baseline) and leave-one-state-out jackknife predictions.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## Baseline Estimates (No Jackknife)

These figures show event study estimates using the full sample to classify counties into high vs. low predicted spending groups.

### Figure 2.1: Spending Only {#fig-1-1}

![Event study estimates by baseline spending quartile (no jackknife)](images/12_9_25/baseline_spec_A_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-1-1-plot}

------------------------------------------------------------------------

![Event study estimates by baseline spending and income quartiles (no jackknife)](images/12_9_25/baseline_spec_B_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-1-2-plot}

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Figure 2.3: Spending + Income * Reform Types {#fig-1-3}

## Jackknife Estimates

These figures use leave-one-state-out predictions to classify counties. For each state, we estimate the model excluding that state's data, then predict spending increases for counties in the excluded state.

### Figure 2.4: Spending Only (Jackknife) {#fig-2-1}

![Jackknife event study estimates - baseline spending only](images/12_9_25/jackknife_spec_A_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-2-1-plot}


------------------------------------------------------------------------

![Jackknife event study estimates - baseline spending and income quartiles](images/12_9_25/jackknife_spec_B_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-2-2-plot}

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Figure 2.6: Spending + Income * Reform Types (Jackknife) {#fig-2-3}

![Jackknife event study estimates - full specification with reforms](images/12_9_25/jackknife_spec_C_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-2-3-plot}

## Sample Composition Analysis: Jackknife vs No Jackknife

This section examines how the jackknife procedure affects sample composition by comparing which observations are classified as high vs. low predicted spending.

### Figure 2.7: Distribution Comparison {#fig-2-7}

![Sample distribution comparison between jackknife and no jackknife approaches](images/12_9_25/no_flip_spec_A_def_A_high_vs_low.png){#fig-2-7-plot}

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Cross-Tabulation: Overall Sample Composition

#### No Jackknife
```
           |      high_def_A
     pre_q |         0          1 |     Total
-----------+----------------------+----------
         1 |    14,840      6,664 |    21,504
         2 |    14,280      6,608 |    20,888
         3 |    14,448      6,608 |    21,056
         4 |    19,936          0 |    19,936
-----------+----------------------+----------
     Total |    63,504     19,880 |    83,384
```

#### Jackknife
```
           |      high_def_A
     pre_q |         0          1 |     Total
-----------+----------------------+----------
         1 |    14,840      6,664 |    21,504
         2 |    14,280      6,608 |    20,888
         3 |    17,136      3,920 |    21,056
         4 |    18,368      1,568 |    19,936
-----------+----------------------+----------
     Total |    64,624     18,760 |    83,384
```

::: {.callout-note}
We can see that some Q3 observations that were in the high group for Q3 moved to low and some observations in the low group for Q4 moved to high. Q1 and Q2 remained the same.
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
